I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  the  operations 
departments of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) implement the transformative goals of ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 by making Water Financing Partnership Facility resources readily accessible to (i) 
prepare and implement innovative projects; (ii) pilot new approaches while bringing them to scale; 
and (iii) help generate and manage knowledge that will result in designing, preparing, and 
implementing better investment projects.1 
 
2.  The TA is included in the ADB Management-approved 2019 results-based work plan of 
ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department. The TA will help ADB’s water 
sector operations achieve all Strategy 2030 goals, particularly the following operational priorities 
(OPs):  (i)  tackling  climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience  and  enhancing 
environmental sustainability (OP3); (ii) making cities more livable (OP4); and (iii) promoting rural 
development and food security (OP5).2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Sector challenges. Asia and the Pacific have seen significant economic growth, but face 
significant water challenges, with an estimated population of 5.2 billion by 2050, including an 
estimated 3.4 billion people in water-stressed areas, and an estimated 80% of the region’s water 
resources used for agriculture.3 With rapid urbanization, the region’s water resources will be under 
enormous pressure by 2030.4 Gender inequality remains pervasive: women’s participation in 
decision-making is limited and the responsibility for collecting water falls largely to women and 
girls, limiting their education and economic opportunities. Climate and land use changes—which 
increase extreme weather events and associated water-related disasters—compound these 
challenges. As a result, water insecurity is prevalent in many developing member countries 
(DMCs) and challenges the achievement of Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 6 to ensure 
the availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all.5 
 
4.  ADB will continue to increase investments and expand its portfolio in the water sector.6 
DMCs need more assistance to improve water resources management and water services 
delivery and overcome the obstacles they face, including (i) insufficient infrastructure investments, 
(ii) poor operation and maintenance and asset management, (iii) inadequate formulation and 
implementation of policies, and (iv) weak institutions and capacity. These obstacles result from a 
combination of institutional, technical, and financial factors, including lack of enabling environment 
for  private  sector  investments  and  the  tendency  to  stick  to  traditional  project  design  and 
knowledge gaps. 
 
5.  Integrated  and  innovative  solutions.  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  promotes  integrated 
solutions moving away from a siloed approach. It encourages (i) high-level technology, (ii) 
emerging innovative solutions, (iii) upscaling best practices, and (iv) private sector engagement

Manila. The Water Financing Partnership Facility was established in November 2006 to provide additional financial 
and knowledge resources from development partners to help implement ADB’s water financing program.

2 
that will help meet the region’s water challenges. To enable this integrated and multisectoral 
paradigm shift, ADB’s operations must better collaborate across water sector divisions and 
enhance cooperation among departments, Office of Public–Private Partnerships, and Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department. ADB operations departments will also enhance 
cooperation  with  the  Independent  Evaluation  Department  to  link  evaluation  lessons  and 
recommendations into the design of new projects. 
 
6.  Strategy 2030’s operational plans call for upscaling best practices and adopting emerging 
innovative solutions to meet the region’s water challenges. For OP3, these include (i) enhanced 
efforts to address water quality, water productivity, and integrated water resources management; 
(ii) strengthening the linkages between water, food and energy; and (iii) enabling integrated 
solutions.7 For OP4, holistic solutions are key, including smart water management, a sponge cities 
approach for flood management, nature-based solutions, and inclusive sanitation to cover both 
networked and non-networked systems.8 For OP5, ensuring food security will require improved 
productivity through modernization of irrigation systems, including automated control systems, 
water reuse, micro irrigation and pressurized piped irrigation.9  Remote-sensing, drone, and smart 
phone applications need upscaling. 
 
7.  ADB assistance and value addition. The TA builds on the good practices and lessons 
learned from the predecessor regional TA10 which include: (i) making additional grant resources 
available to operations departments to engage with DMC governments in developing stronger 
pipeline of water investments; (ii) supporting sector policy dialogue to inform institutional reforms 
in DMCs; (iii) pilot testing new and/or innovative concepts, approaches, strategies and business 
models, including new technologies, to facilitate dissemination of emerging innovations and newer 
thinking; (iv) promoting peer-to-peer learning and practitioner-focused technical training following 
the model of the Water Operators Partnerships (WOPs) Program; and (v) increasing knowledge 
base through analytical work, research, and collaboration with knowledge partners to inform 
ADB’s water operations.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: availability and sustainable management of 
water and sanitation ensured for all (SDG 6).11 The TA will have the following outcome: knowledge 
and capacity for water resources management and water services delivery in DMCs improved.12 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1. Project design and implementation support, and pilot and demonstration 
activities provided. The TA will provide project design and implementation support (PDIS) to 
 
7  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 3: Tackling Climate Change, Building Climate and Disaster 
Resilience, and Enhancing Environmental Sustainability, 2019–2024. Manila. 
8  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 4: Making Cities More Livable, 2019–2024. Manila. 
9  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 5: Promoting Rural Development and Food Security, 2019–
2024. Manila. 
10 ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance for Knowledge and Innovation Support for ADB’s Water Financing Program. Manila 
(TA 6498-REG) will close in December 2020 and activities are targeted to be completed no later than September 
2020. Having this new TA in place before 2020 will facilitate smoother transition and uninterrupted support to 
operations departments. 
11 United Nations. 2015. Transforming our World: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. New York.

3 
operations departments on demand through specialists’ inputs and/or other services, starting from 
upstream  work  (pre-concept  phase)  all  the  way  through  transaction  TA  and  project 
implementation.  The  TA  will  supplement  complex  and  innovative  projects  that  require 
complementary technical, policy and institutional support from  expert inputs. The scope of 
specialists’ services will cover the five Water Sector Group activities: (i) supplying water, (ii) water 
quality and sanitation, (iii) water for food, (iv) water for energy, (v) water resources management, 
and (vi) disaster risk reduction. It will also cover the following crosscutting issues: (i) promoting 
inclusiveness and health, (ii) governance and sustainability, (iii) financing and transactions, (iv) 
disaster and resilience, (v) high-level technology, and (v) integration and water-food-energy nexus.   
 
10.  TA resources will also be directed at pilot and demonstration activities (PDAs) of less than 
$75,000  to  test  and  validate  innovative  concepts,  strategies,  business  models,  and  new 
technologies, including applied research that can be replicated and scaled up.13 As experience 
shows, PDAs serve as a quick-response mechanism for operations departments when the need 
to test something on the ground arises for which there is no readily available instrument. PDAs 
can support operations departments through (i) design options during project development; (ii) 
innovative  solutions  during  project  implementation;  (iii)  engagement  with  government 
counterparts and other stakeholders; and (iv) stimulating development of new investments. 
 
11.  Results of PDIS and PDAs will be documented for sharing across operations departments 
to support preparation and implementation of future projects. 
 
12.  Output  2.  Knowledge  management,  strategic  collaborations,  and  capacity 
development supported. Output 2 will strengthen ADB’s role as a knowledge partner, including 
by (i) enhancing knowledge management to help capture ADB’s tacit operational knowledge and 
share lessons with DMCs through knowledge products in accessible formats and (2) promoting 
DMC peer-to-peer learning. To develop knowledge products, the TA will deliberately select project 
lessons that provide good practices for replication. It will also include analytical work such as 
ADB’s flagship publication (Asian Water Development Outlook), and the development of print and 
non-print knowledge products, including video blogs, web-based materials, and social media. The 
TA  will  optimize  the  Water  Sector  Group  community  site  on  SharePoint  to  increase  the 
sustainability of knowledge-sharing platforms after TA completion. The TA will also help prepare 
ADB flagship events and actively participate in partner-organized events in collaboration with 
operations departments and in-country workshops and conferences to help share knowledge on 
a demand basis and disseminate practical knowledge within ADB.14 To complement ADB’s 
knowledge and capacity, the TA will support strategic collaborations with partners using various 
modalities to share expertise, including continuous learning and development activities for ADB 
and DMC staff.15 The TA will support capacity-building activities to complement projects or TA 
projects, such as peer-to-peer learnings, twinning partnerships, and the WOPs program. 
 
 
13 PDAs started in 2002 under the Water Financing Partnership Facility’s predecessor, the Cooperation Fund for the 
Water Sector, and they have been sustained under Water Financing Partnership Facility and TA 6498. Examples of 
PDA results that benefited ADB’s in-country work include (i) improved policy for tariff setting in the Philippines; (ii) 
mobilization of communities for sanitation, hygiene, and river cleanup in the People’s Republic of China; and (iii) 
empowerment of women and disadvantaged farmers in Nepal. To date, the Water Financing Partnership Facility has 
supported a total of 63 PDAs.  
14 ADB flagship events include the Asia Water Forum, Asian Irrigation Forum, Asian Sanitation Dialogue, and 
Roundtable on Financing Water. Partner-organized events include Stockholm World Water Week, World Water 
Forum, International Fecal Sludge Management Conference, Asia International Water Week, Singapore International 
Water Week, International River Symposium, and Asia–Pacific Water Summit. 
15 Asia-Netherlands Water Learning Week, ADB–Australia Water Learning Week, and other technical trainings.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,250,000, of which (i) $250,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund; and (ii) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Netherlands Trust Fund, both under the Water Financing Partnership Facility and administered 
by ADB.16 Key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA.  The Water Sector Group under the Sector Advisory Service 
Cluster of ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department will carry out TA 
administration  and  supervise  implementation  in  close  collaboration  with  the  Water  Sector 
Committee, operations departments including ADB resident missions, and other sector and 
thematic groups.

specialists can be funded directly from the Water Financing Partnership Facility through the direct 
charge modality or a TA. Proposals may be submitted any time using a proposal template 
developed under ADB’s regional TA for Knowledge and Innovation Support for ADB’s Water 
Financing Program. Following approval of funding, the user division may proceed to engage 
specialists. 
 
17.  Pilot testing of project approach. PDAs may involve selecting consultants, procuring 
goods and works, and collaborating with partners. PDAs should be directly linked to project 
preparation or implementation. Proposals may be submitted any time using the existing PDA 
proposal template. The maximum amount for each proposal is $75,000 and the maximum 
implementation period is 12 months. ADB staff will be the PDA proponents and hence will be 
responsible for procurement, management, and progress reporting on the activities, including a 
PDA completion report summarizing findings and recommendations on the potential for replication 
and scaling up. For PDAs that involve civil works, all permits and clearances that may be required 
shall be the responsibility of the government recipient of the TA funds. ADB staff submitting PDA 
applications  that  involve  civil  works  will  be  responsible  for  preparing  the  memorandum  of 
understanding between ADB and the government that stipulates the responsibility, among others, 
of the government recipient for securing permits and clearances and arranging the treatment of 
assets. Following PDA approval, commencement of civil works will be allowed only after the 
memorandum of understanding has been signed and issues associated with permits and licenses 
have been resolved. Assets procured under the PDA shall be turned over to the government upon 
completion of the pilot project. PDAs involving partners should cost-share so that partnering 
institutions bear a portion of the project cost, which may be in-kind (including experts’ cost, land, 
office space, labor). Every PDA should develop a knowledge product to the degree possible. 
These activities will not result in any potential adverse environmental and/or social impacts. 
 
18.  ADB’s procurement. The procurement method to be used for goods and/or works is 
competitive bidding. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy and Procurement 
Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time).18 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Netherlands Trust Fund; and (ii) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund, both under the Water Financing Partnership Facility 
for Achieving Water Sector Priorities in Asia and the Pacific under Strategy 2030, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
